Fields.DialogueText: Steady as she goes. This is a good course for our approach to the harbor.
Mahan, did you hear me?
Oh? Yes! Sorry.
Steady as she goes. Aye aye, Captain.
Focus, Mahan. We have a lot of civilian traffic out here. Let's not hit anyone.
Sigh, I know. I just don't want to see him go.
Mr. Holtman can't stay on board with us forever, Mahan. We have to drop him off today.
It was so great having such a brilliant thinker on board, someone who I could talk to about tactics and strategy and, well... everything!

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you enjoyed his visit. It sounds like you learned a lot.
That's nice, but the sooner he's gone, the better. We have a war to fight.
Well, you can always talk to me about things, too. I am your captain, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: I did! My head feels like it's full of great new ideas.
I know, but I'm still sad to see him go.
Oh! I'm sorry, Captain. I didn't mean to insult you.
Command needs us back at sea. Once we're there, you can put all of that new knowledge into practice.
We're almost at the harbor. Do you mind if I head down and say goodbye?
No problem, but don't take too long. Once he's safely on the pier, I need you back in the bridge.
Yes, Captain! I just need enough time for him to sign this book before he goes. I'll be right back!
Mahan!
Yes, Captain?
You left your book up here.
*ALARM*
Right... thanks! I’ll pick it up after the battle!
*sigh*
@BATTLE
Heh, you didn't. Don't worry about it.
Reporting as ordered, Captain.
Have a look at these charts.
A northeast rhumb line, running across the Atlantic?
That's right.
It's a textbook transit from here to England. Am I missing something?
Not a thing, Mahan. We're heading east to England, and I wanted you to see the battlefield.
Technically it's an ocean, not a field.

Fields.MenuText: You've always had an eye for details.
Should we call it a "battle ocean"?
It's just a figure of speech, Mahan.

Fields.DialogueText: An ear, you mean?
Hee hee! Point taken, Captain. "Battlefield" it is.
Of course. Sorry, Captain. You were saying?
Either way, this is where we have to be ready to fight.
I understand.
You're my tactical expert, so get us ready. We run a good chance of seeing some Morganas on our way to England.
Correct, Captain. According to the latest combat reports, that chance is approximately 100 percent.
Review your new tactics and make sure we're ready.
Studying tactics is what I do best, Captain. I'll get started right away.
Don't get lost in the books for too long. Morganas could show up at–
*ALARM*
...any time.
@BATTLE
Mahan? Are you in there? Open up!
Sorry, Captain! Just a second.
There you are. Mahan, you'd better have a good reason for locking me out of my own cabin.
It wasn't locked. I just had to move some books out of the way to open the door.
I noticed those.
I also noticed the books on my desk.
Those are...
And the books on my mattress.
Well...

Fields.MenuText: You've been doing a lot of research.
My cabin can't be your personal library, Mahan.
Stuff any more books in here and we'll sink!

Fields.DialogueText: I don't take any job lightly.
I started reading and... I guess I lost track of where I was.
That wouldn't actually happen. It would actually take more books than–
I've gathered all these strategy books so we can be better prepared for whatever comes our way.
Books are great, but it's also important that you maintain your situational awareness.
Situational awareness? Oh. You mean your cabin.
My cabin.
Right. I'll get these books moved somewhere else.
Thanks, Mahan.
*ALARM*
Morganas. Looks like it will have to wait.
I won't forget to move the books after the fight!
@BATTLE
Figure of speech, Mahan.
Oh. Right.
Thanks for the training notes, Mahan. I'll make sure the other officers study these right away.
Great, thanks so much for the help. See you tomorrow!
See you then.
I'm impressed, Mahan.
Captain?
You've become more assertive about dealing with the officers on board.
Ah! Thank you, Captain. I appreciate that. McNamara has helped a lot, in that respect.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you're enjoying it.
I'm eager to see results.
You two do spend a lot of time together...

Fields.DialogueText: I'm really coming into my own, don't you think?
You can count on me, Captain!
I–I'm not sure what you're implying.
With all of these Morgana patrols, we'll need our officers to be as prepared as possible if we want to survive.
I'll do my best to prepare us.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Nice work yesterday, Mahan. You did a great job seeing us through that last skirmish with the Morganas.
Thank you, Captain.
It looks like your training is making us more effective.
The officers are more deliberate with their gunfire, just like I've been teaching them.
How so?
They used to waste a lot of ammunition by shooting as soon as they saw a Morgana. Now they wait until we're in a good firing position.
Then it sounds like we're ready.
Ready for what, exactly?
Just bring me the after-action report. I have an idea.
Aye aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You called for me, Captain?
I did. Have a seat, because I have some big news for you.
That makes me nervous. I think I'll stand, if that's all right.
That's fine.
Command needs someone to lead a major task force. I volunteered us to lead it.
*gulp* You did what?!
With all of your tactical expertise, you're the best Belle for the job.
Me? Coordinating a whole task force? I don't know...

Fields.MenuText: Have some confidence. You got us this far.
Is it too much for you to handle? I don't want to disappoint Command.
Really? I thought you'd be eager to show off your knowledge of naval tactics.

Fields.DialogueText: I... I guess so, Captain.
And I don't want to disappoint you, Captain.
I am, but maybe in a classroom?
We have a war to win. It's time to put all of your reading and studying into practice.
If you say so, Captain, but I need time to get ready.
Be ready by the time we get to England. That's where we'll meet the rest of the task force.
I need...
I need more books! I have to start preparing right now.
*ALARM*
Looks like it will have to wait, Mahan.
@BATTLE
*groan*
Mahan? Are you feeling all right?
I am... fine, Captain.
You don't look fine. You've been pacing up and down the passageway for almost half an hour, muttering and making moaning sounds.
My head... My head...

Fields.MenuText: Are you anxious about working with the task force?
Did you take a bad hit in the last combat?
Did you forget your morning coffee?

Fields.DialogueText: No, it's worse than that...
No, it's worse than that...
No, it's worse than that...
Mahan? You're scaring me.
I need a NEWSPAPER!
What?!
Oh, Captain, I'm so sorry for yelling, but we haven't gotten any newspapers since we left New York. Not having my daily paper is making my brain hurt!
You had me scared. I thought it was something serious.
This is serious. I can't concentrate. I need a newspaper to settle down.
Maybe one of the crew has an old paper that you haven't read yet. I'll find one for you.
Thanks, Captain.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I've been hearing a chattering noise for the past few nautical miles. Do we have a problem in the engine room?
It's prob-b-b-bably just me, C-c-captain.
That chattering noise was your teeth?
We're getting closer to the North Sea. I'm still getting used to the weather up here. Brr!

Fields.MenuText: Put on a coat.
It isn't that cold. You're just nervous about the task force.
Maybe we could steer a little bit further south to warm up?

Fields.DialogueText: Easy for you to say, Captain. You don't have to feel the hull of the ship in the cold water like I do.
There is some truth to that, Captain.
Spain sounds lovely, but I know we have a job to do up here.
Don't worry. Eventually I'll get used to it.
Well, maybe this cup of coffee will help a little bit while you do.
Thanks, Captain.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Mahan, I have something for you. This is the order of battle for our task force.
A listing of all the ships we'll be working with?
Yes. Here you go.
Thanks, Captain. And now, I have something for you.
What is it?
It's a logistics request. I need a few more supplies before we get started.
Oh. Here, let me just sign that.
There you go. Request approved.
You didn't even read it.

Fields.MenuText: I trust you. Just a few office supplies, right? Get this to the yeoman and send it out.
If you think we need it, then we need it. You're the ship, you know yourself better than we do.
Eh, the Navy will cover the cost. Anything's fine with me.

Fields.DialogueText: ...Thanks, Captain. I'll take care of it right away.
I hadn't seen it like that…
That's oddly laid back of you.
Once you're free, I want you looking at that order of battle. We're going to need our tactical expert Belle to lead us.
Aye aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Mahan, get up here to the bridge immediately!
Coming!
Reporting as ordered, Captain. What is it?
See that rusty cargo ship sneaking up on us from astern?
Sneaking up? I don't understand. That cargo ship is just here to deliver my supplies.
A few pens and pencils? One of the task force ships should have our delivery.
The order was too big for that. They sent that cargo ship to help out.
It's only a few crates. Forty typewriters and three hundred reams of paper. I can see the crates on her deck from here.
What?
Would you like to use my binoculars?

Fields.MenuText: No. I can see the problem clearly from here.
Yes. I need them to look for your common sense. It fell overboard somewhere.
Forty typewriters?! What are you going to do with forty typewriters?!

Fields.DialogueText: What problem?
Oh, Captain...
I was going to enlist the help of the officers to assist in typing up all of my battle plans for the task force, Captain.
We don't need all of that. It's far too much.
I just wanted to make sure I was prepared.
I know, I know. I should have read that logistics request before signing it.
I'm sorry, Captain.
Let's take just two extra typewriters and some paper, and then get moving.
I'll hurry. I get the feeling that a few Morganas might show up soon.
Do you sense them nearby?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
How are things looking on the bridge wing? The winds are bracing out here.
We do have choppy seas today.
Are you acclimated to the colder waters now?
I'm doing much better, thank you.
Is everyone else here at the rendezvous?
Yes, Captain. All six ships in our task force have acknowledged us on the radio.
Two submarines, three frigates, and two other destroyers. So seven of them in total, then.
A lucky number for us, I hope.

Fields.MenuText: I like your optimism, Mahan.
Lucky? I didn't think you were the superstitious type.
Let's start getting organized.

Fields.DialogueText: We're in charge, so we have to set the tone for the group.
It was just an observation.
Aye aye, Captain!
I'm still a bit nervous about leading the task force, if I'm to be completely honest.
We need to be ready for...
*ALARM*
A Morgana raid. It's starting!
@BATTLE
Can I come in? It's urgent!
Whatever it is, it can wait until after this battle!.
@BATTLE
Are you all right? You look a little more... weary than I'm used to seeing you after a raid.
No, I'm not all right!
Are you hurt? Did the damage control teams miss something?
No, Captain. It's the rest of the task force. They just sat there.
Why didn't they help us out in that fight?

Fields.MenuText: They were afraid.
We forgot to tell them.
They were caught off guard.

Fields.DialogueText: That just can't be. It must be something else.
What?
For the whole battle? That doesn't seem right.
Contact the other ships and figure it out. I'll be waiting for your after-action report.
*sigh*
Here's my after-action report.
I hope you can have the next one as fast as you had this one.
The next one?
Look starboard.
@BATTLE
Ugh, that was exhausting. Anyway, I have some bad news, Captain.
Good or bad, we just have to deal with it. Go ahead, Mahan.
The other task force ships reported that they did not contribute significantly when the Morganas attacked because we didn't give them any orders.
Hm. Did you give them any?
Well... no. But they still should have done something, right?

Fields.MenuText: Did you expect them to start shooting before they were told?
Maybe it was too confusing, and without a clear plan, they didn't want to risk friendly fire.
We're the task force leader.

Fields.DialogueText: A little bit! I mean, the Morganas were right there!
I see what you mean.
I still think they should have helped.
Like it or not, they were right to wait for instructions.
I guess that means they're well-disciplined, at least.
Yes. And we can't expect them to read our minds. We have to give them clear orders next time.
That gives me an idea. I'm going to take care of this problem right away, Captain!
If this idea involves more typewriters...
Form One. Golf Corpen Zero Two Zero. Standby.
Execute.
Zero Two Zero, roger.
Zero Two Zero, roger.
Formation drills. Interesting.
Yes, Captain. Those two frigates are moving to position now. Their maneuvers are sharp.

Fields.MenuText: Working on fundamentals as a team. Great plan.
Isn't this a bit too... basic?
I don't think Morganas will be defeated by snappy turns.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain.
No, not at all, Captain.
Has anyone told you that your sense of humor is a bit too dry?
Soldiers march and maneuver together to work as a team. It's the same for ships.
Good point. It also gets them used to receiving and executing our commands.
And it gets me used to giving them.
Keep practicing.
I want to prove that I am up to this challenge. At sea, not just in a pile of books.
We're going to find out soon.
I... Oh. I sense them now.
Let's get those two frigates to help out this time!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Everyone, to your stations! We're about to be raided!
@BATTLE
Whew! My arms are tired!
They should be. You were out there waving those flags and hoisting pennants for a long time.
It was thrilling to practice such a...
Traditional?
Precisely. A traditional means of tactical communication.

Fields.MenuText: A radio still works better, if you ask me.
It could be handy in some situations, especially if the radio doesn't work.
Too bad you can't use flags to communicate at night.

Fields.DialogueText: In most cases, yes. But some of the greatest naval commanders didn't have radios.
Or if you want to maintain radio silence, Captain.
At night you could use Morse code with signal lamps, Captain.
Some of the other ships were rusty with their signal flag skills, but they are getting better.
What matters to me is that they're working as a team. And that you are working as their leader.
I'm doing my best.
Keep up the good work. We don't know how much time we have until Command wants us to move out.
Aye aye, Captain.
Normally, I can hear her typing one hundred words per minute in there, but now it's quiet.
She must be done writing her task force plans, so it should be safe to enter.
Mahan? Can I come in?
AAAGH!
I mean, "Yes, Captain."
I couldn't hear your typewriter from the corridor. Are you done with the task force plans?
Done? Hardly! Would you rush Ulysses S. Grant as he plans how to defeat the confederates?
I asked you to prepare a brief sheet for the other captains in the task force. Brief. What's going on in here?
I'm preparing an informative booklet of tactical priorities, secret codes, and contingency plans for each ship in our task force.
I think that–
I've also included a comprehensive history of weather patterns in this area.
So you're done?
Not yet. Right now I'm working on a brief history of Morgana patrol patterns and combat behavior in this region.
How brief?
Let me see.
Ninety-eight pages.
I see. Mahan, we need to have a talk about this.
I'm in trouble? Darn it! But I was working so hard!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain?
Come in.
Would you like some coffee? I've had so much to drink that I can't finish this pot.
Thanks. Did you get that brief sheet trimmed down to size?
I did. Here.
Let's see.
This looks good. I'll arrange for the other captains to come over.
I heard that Command contacted us with our first orders for the task group.
They did. After the captains' meeting, we're heading to the Norwegian Sea to scout for Morgana rally points.
It's finally happening... We're going to do it.

Fields.MenuText: We certainly are.
Don't get cold feet now.
You're going to do great.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope my training and practicing were enough.
My feet are cold enough right here in the North Sea. The Norwegian Sea? Brr!
Thanks, Captain. I needed that.
Get some rest, but be ready for Morgana scouts.
They seem to enjoy harassing our little fleet out here.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
This course to the Norwegian Sea will take us close to the Faroe Islands.
I see our task force is following in formation. Nice work with the training, Mahan.
Thank you, Captain.
Those islands are beautiful. Keep your nose out of the newspapers and take a good look when we pass them by.
I'll be sure to remember that.
It's a shame that the Morganas seem to like these waters so much.
Perhaps we can figure out why they do. Many tacticians and strategists put high value on knowing one's opponent.
Funny you should say that. That's why Command wants our task force to head north. They're hoping we can find an answer to that question.
Do you have any hunches, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe they like stormy waters and bad weather.
Maybe they have some sort of base up north.
I don't think there's any reason. The Morganas seem to be everywhere.

Fields.DialogueText: That wouldn't surprise me one bit.
Oh, I hope that isn't true. I don't want to do any sightseeing in a place like that.
Well, we have to try anyway.
Keep our group in tight formation. I don't want anyone getting lost.
Aye aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
If I thought it was cold before, I was wrong. This is cold. Brrr!
And choppy. It smells like a few sailors have gotten seasick.
Yuck.
You wanted to show me something?
Well, Captain, we've been fighting off Morgana attacks since we headed north. For some time now, I've been trying to find a pattern in those attacks. If we look at the direction of each attack...
I understand. If we trace their courses back to the point of origin, they would seem to be coming from a place right about...
Here.
In that case, we're really close. If we're nearing the center...

Fields.MenuText: ...we should scout the area carefully.
...we should turn back. This might be too dangerous for our little task force.
...we should put the task force in a formation that is ready for an attack from any direction.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll have us ready, Captain. We'll use our submarines and frigates as picket ships.
We can't go back now. Trust me to see this through.
I was afraid you might say that.
Make sure the radio is ready. This is exactly the intel that Command sent us up here to get.
Aye aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
If you say so, Mahan.
Captain! Captain! Please meet me over at– *gasp* ...the chart table.
On my way. Mahan, take a deep breath first, then tell me.
Yes, of course.
Our submarines detected unusual noises along this bearing... here.
Classification?
They couldn't classify it, but they reported that it wasn't regular Morgana sounds.
Interesting.
That correlates to where one of our frigates spotted six Morganas suddenly appearing on the horizon right about... here.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe it's a vulnerable spot for them, and they don't want us to find it.
Maybe it's some kind of hive, where a queen is hatching more Morganas.
I honestly have no idea.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope you're right. It would explain why they keep attacking us.
That's... that's horrifying, Captain.
Me neither, Captain.
Whatever it is, it could be valuable to our superiors.
Is that good enough for Command, then? Can we go now?
I'm afraid not. We still need to know more about what exactly the Morganas are doing there.
*sigh* I understand, Captain.
Take our task force in for a closer look, and expect some resistance.
@BATTLE
To keep us away? Exactly.
*ALARM*
Dammit! The captain isn't going to be happy with me...
And exactly why is that, Mahan?
O-oh... no reason.
Mahan...
*sigh* After that last fight, the task force was separated. There were some, well, losses.

Fields.MenuText: Get on the radio right now. Call them up.
Did you see where they were headed?
Did anyone see them go down?

Fields.DialogueText: I already tried. Maybe it's the storm, but I couldn't contact them.
With all of that rain, I lost sight of them.
Goodness, Captain! I hope not! Now I'm really worried about them!
Then all we can do is hope they show up.
Ugh.
Do you have something else to say?
With our losses, the plans I made are useless. We'll need new formations, long range tactics, short range tactics...
We might not have time for all of that. We might have to...
No! Don't say it!
...improvise.
Nooooo!
And we might have to begin doing it now!
@BATTLE
This was a bad idea. We shouldn't have penetrated this far past the Morgana screens, especially while our task force is still damaged.
There goes another Morgana patrol.
I'm watching them, Captain.
Look
Settle your nerves, Mahan. We're not dead yet.
I'm not so sure about that. It could be a trick to lure us in.

Fields.MenuText: Is that your tactical assessment of the situation?
Don't frighten yourself. Or the rest of us, for that matter.
Maybe you're right. This might be a trap.

Fields.DialogueText: It is.
I can't help it. When the Morganas find us, they'll surround us like hungry sharks.
I'm getting that feeling, too.
All right. You convinced me, Mahan. We'll back off and report what we observed here to Command. It's still good intel to investigate later.
Thanks for trusting me, Captain. I wouldn't want us to– Oh no!
Damn! Where did that line of Morganas come from? There must be twenty of them, at least!
It was a trap!
We need to get out of here. I need a tactical recommendation, Mahan.
Um...
Mahan.
Uh...
I got it! We break through to the southeast. That's where the line is weakest. If we can get past them, we might be able to outrun the rest.
What about the submarines? They can't keep up with us at full speed.
The submarines will have to hide, but the frigates can still follow us out.
Good thinking, Mahan. You're giving us a fighting chance.
@BATTLE
Based on what?
I can't explain it. I just... sense it.
I don't know how much longer I can keep running. I'm... so... tired!
Keep the engines turning, Mahan. It's all or nothing now.
I can feel the rest of those Morganas at our heels. They're catching up. We aren't going to get away, are we?
*BOOM*
What was that? Did one of our engines just explode?
I don't think so...
Look! One of the Morganas chasing us is on fire!
It's the fleet we had lost! It made it back to the task force!
I knew they'd find us!
Some of the Morganas are splitting off to face them.

Fields.MenuText: Let's hope they can turn the tide.
Let's hope they can buy us enough time to escape.
Let's hope the Morganas are so intimidated by our firepower that they all take their own lives in horror.

Fields.DialogueText: I've analyzed their position. We can do this!
They can do more than that. Look at the Morgana formation!
Captain, this is a serious situation! Although that doesn't sound so terrible...
The fleet took them completely by surprise! The Morganas are in rotten position now against its main guns.
Then open fire! Give them everything you have left!
All right! Let's see them try to keep up with a master tactician! YAH!
@BATTLE
Captain? Did we... did we win? I...  I think I need a break.
*THUD*
Mahan!
Officer, do you have news about Mahan?
I'm sorry, Captain, no news about her. However, I do have news about...
*ALARM*
...that.
@BATTLE
Is Mahan going to be all right, Captain? Aside from battles, I've rarely seen her around the ship.
I just talked to the medic. She's taken some big hits recently, Ensign, but she's tough. With rest, she'll recover fully soon enough.
She trained us. I hope we're not disappointing her in battle.
I'm sure you aren't.
McNamara?
It took some work to convince her to rest and not work after that last battle, but she finally saw reason.
I do appreciate your helping me in looking after her.
I'm happy to do it, Captain.
When can we see her?
I'll have McNamara let you know when she's ready. Until then, get back to your stations.
Aye aye, Captain.
With any luck, she'll be ready sooner rather than later.
*ALARM*
Dammit, we need Mahan! But I cannot rush her recovery. I hope she's healing fast.
@BATTLE
*yawn*
Well, good morning, Mahan.
Is it morning?
It doesn't matter. You're looking brighter-eyed, and that's what counts.
I'm still a little worn out, but I think I'm nearly recovered.
Glad to hear it. The officers and crew will be happy to hear that, too.
I didn't mean to scare anyone, but I knew I needed to push myself. For the good of the task force.
Wait...
Is everyone all right? Did all of the task force ships manage to escape?

Fields.MenuText: We all did, thanks to you.
We mopped up the Morganas. The team performed admirably under pressure.
I doubt I'd be smiling if the task force had met any other fate.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain. The credit is shared, I'm sure.
In that case, I'm happy I spent as much time training them as I did.
Haha! That's true, Captain!
Captain, you took care of me, challenged me, and made me stronger. I'm glad I have you for a friend.
You did the same for me. A captain couldn't ask for a better right hand.
I think I'll get up and get some coffee now.
I already brought you some. Stay here and rest a little more.
Aye aye, Captain. Can I make a request?
Name it.
Please bring me a typewriter. I need to write a letter to the task force congratulating them on their success.
A brief letter?
Of course.
No more than a hundred pages, I promise.
Naturally.
